title: Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
objectives: Demonstrate short-field takeoff technique for obstacle clearance
Achieve VX for maximum angle of climb
Transition to VY after obstacle clearance
Identify and correct common short-field errors
overview: Short-field takeoffs are critical for operations from confined areas. This lesson teaches maximum performance technique: full power before brake release, rotation at minimum speed, and VX climb for obstacle clearance.

keyPoints: Every knot counts in obstacle clearance

keyTeachingPoints: VX is for angle (obstacle clearance), VY is for rate
Full power before brake release
Use all available runway
Rotate at VX -5 knots for ground acceleration
Hold VX until obstacle cleared, then VY
commonErrors: Climbing at VY instead of VX
Relaxing after liftoff - speed bleeds off

diagrams.title: VX vs VY
diagrams.description: VX = steepest climb angle (obstacle clearance), VY = best rate of climb (altitude gain)
diagrams.asciiArt:
VX: Steep angle, slower
 ↗↗↗
VY: Shallower angle, faster
  ↗↗

suggestedHomework: Calculate takeoff distance for various conditions
instructorNotes: Safety: Ensure adequate runway length
Watch for student over-rotation
safetyConsiderations: Stall speed increases with bank - no turns low
Be ready to take controls if airspeed decays

title: Short-Field Approach and Landing
objectives: Touch down at minimum controllable airspeed
Land within first 200 feet of target
Execute go-around if target point cannot be made
overview: Short-field landings require precision and technique. Students learn obstacle clearance approaches, precise airspeed control, minimum float landings, and maximum braking.

keyPoints: Power controls descent, pitch controls speed
Aim for landing zone, not before

keyTeachingPoints: Approach speed 1.3 Vso (typically 10 kts slower than normal)
Steeper approach clears obstacles better
Touch down on target, not before
Immediate heavy braking after nose wheel down
Full flaps for steeper descent
Go-around if target will be missed
commonErrors: Approaching too fast - long float and landing
Attempting to salvage bad approach instead of going around

diagrams.title: Short-Field Approach
diagrams.description: Steeper approach angle with obstacle clearance

completionStandards.standard: Touch down within 200 feet beyond target

notes: Practice with runway markers before real short fields
Weight and wind dramatically affect landing distance
instructorNotes: Emphasize go-around decision-making
Watch for student landing short of target
safetyConsiderations: Never land short to hit target
Monitor for nose wheel damage with hard braking

title: Go-Around / Rejected Landing
objectives: Maintain directional control during power application
Teach that go-arounds are normal, not failures
overview: The go-around is a critical safety maneuver that students must execute without hesitation. This lesson covers decision-making, technique, and overcoming the psychological barrier to rejecting a landing.

studentActions: Memorize CCCC: Carb heat, Cram throttle, Climb attitude, Clean up

instructorActions: From flare, from short final, from base
keyPoints: Go-around is automatic response to unstable approach

keyTeachingPoints: Go-around is a normal procedure, not a failure
Decision to go-around must be immediate and positive
Full power smoothly - right rudder immediately
Pitch for VY to avoid settling
Retract flaps incrementally to avoid sink
Announce 'Going around' on radio
Don't try to salvage bad approaches
commonErrors: Pitching up before adding power - settling
Retracting flaps all at once - sinking

diagrams.title: Go-Around Sequence
diagrams.asciiArt:
1. CARB HEAT cold
2. CRAM throttle (full power)
3. CLIMB attitude (VY)
4. CLEAN UP (flaps incrementally)

completionStandards.standard: Make timely decision to discontinue approach
Apply full power and establish pitch for VY
Retract flaps and maintain VY +10/-5 knots

notes: First solo go-around often surprises students
Practice from all points in approach
instructorNotes: Create realistic scenarios for go-arounds
Praise decisive go-around decisions
safetyConsiderations: Monitor for settling with power application
Brief that low-altitude go-arounds are high-risk - need smooth technique

title: Maneuvering During Slow Flight
objectives: Establish and maintain slow flight configuration
Perform turns, climbs, and descents in slow flight
Recognize aerodynamic buffet and control feel
overview: Slow flight teaches students to recognize and operate near the stall, develop fine touch, and understand low-speed aerodynamics. This is foundational for stall training and landing pattern work.

keyPoints: Slow flight is not minimum controllable airspeed
High angle of attack, high power required

instructorActions: Add back pressure as speed decreases
keyPoints: High power needed to maintain altitude

instructorActions: Lower nose, add power, accelerate, clean up

keyTeachingPoints: Slow flight is fully controllable flight just above stall
High angle of attack requires high power
Controls are 'mushy' but still effective
Adverse yaw is pronounced - extra rudder needed
Altitude control is almost entirely power
Pitch for airspeed, power for altitude (reversed from cruise)
Stall horn may sound - this is normal
commonErrors: Chasing altitude with pitch instead of power

diagrams.title: Power Required Curve
diagrams.description: Shows high power needed at slow speeds

completionStandards.standard: Establish slow flight at 1.5 Vs to stall warning
Maintain specified bank angle ±10° in turns

notes: This maneuver builds finesse and confidence
Essential for understanding landing pattern speeds
suggestedHomework: Read about coefficient of lift and drag
instructorNotes: Watch for student discomfort - encourage relaxation
Expect large altitude excursions initially
safetyConsiderations: Be ready for secondary stall on recovery

title: Power-Off Stalls
overview: Power-off stalls simulate approach-to-landing configuration stalls. Students learn to recognize imminent stalls and execute prompt recovery: lower nose, add power, roll wings level, return to straight and level.

studentActions: Memorize recovery: Lower nose, power, level wings, climb
keyPoints: Stall is about angle of attack, not airspeed

instructorActions: Recover: nose down, power, level, climb
keyPoints: Stall warner activates 5-10 kts before stall

studentActions: Recover at first indication or full stall

keyPoints: In real life: prevent stall, don't practice recovery

keyTeachingPoints: Power-off stall simulates approach-to-landing stall
Proper recovery: reduce angle of attack immediately
Prompt recovery minimizes altitude loss
Add power to accelerate recovery
Level wings if in turn
Return to straight-and-level flight
Altitude loss is acceptable - preventing secondary stall is priority
commonErrors: Excessive back pressure before stall - abrupt break
Not releasing back pressure enough in recovery
Adding power before reducing angle of attack
Secondary stall - pulling out of dive too aggressively

diagrams.title: Stall Recovery
diagrams.asciiArt:
1. PUSH (reduce angle of attack)
2. POWER (full throttle)
3. ROLL (wings level)
4. RECOVER (return to level flight)

completionStandards.standard: Establish landing configuration and approach attitude
Recognize and announce first indication of stall

notes: Student anxiety is normal - normalize stalls
instructorNotes: Watch for student tension - encourage breathing
Ensure clearing turns before each stall
safetyConsiderations: Monitor for uncoordinated entry - spin risk

title: Power-On Stalls
overview: Power-on stalls simulate takeoff and departure configuration stalls. Students learn to manage high power, high angle of attack situations and recognize departure stall risks.

instructorActions: Full power, pitch up to stall
Recover: release back pressure, level wings

keyPoints: Right rudder, right rudder, right rudder
Departure stalls are preventable with awareness

keyTeachingPoints: Power-on stall simulates departure/go-around stall
High power creates strong left-turning tendencies
Right rudder essential for coordination
Nose attitude is very high at stall
Wing drop indicates uncoordinated flight
Recovery: release back pressure, level wings, maintain power unless specified
In real life: avoid by proper pitch attitude on climbout

diagrams.title: Left-Turning Tendencies
diagrams.description: High power effects requiring right rudder
diagrams.asciiArt:
← Torque
← P-factor (descending blade)
← Slipstream
Result: Need RIGHT RUDDER →→

instructorNotes: Emphasize rudder coordination throughout
Watch for student surprise at high nose attitude
safetyConsiderations: Monitor ball - coordination critical to prevent spin

title: Steep Turns
objectives: Perform both left and right steep turns
overview: Steep turns develop precise airplane control at increased load factors. Students learn to manage pitch, power, and bank while understanding aerodynamic principles of turning flight.

studentActions: Understand stall speed increases in turns
keyPoints: Lead rollout by half bank angle (22°)

instructorActions: Roll to 45°, add back pressure and power

keyPoints: Left turn different from right (torque effects)

keyTeachingPoints: 45° bank angle ±5° required
Altitude control requires increased back pressure
Power increase (100-200 RPM) needed to maintain airspeed
Load factor increases to 1.4 G at 45° bank
Stall speed increases by 20%
Lead rollout by 20-22° to avoid overshooting
Clearing turns before entry required
Constant visual scan prevents spatial disorientation
commonErrors: Not enough back pressure - altitude loss

diagrams.title: Load Factor in Turns
diagrams.asciiArt:
Level: 1.0 G
30° bank: 1.15 G
45° bank: 1.41 G ← Steep turns
60° bank: 2.0 G

suggestedHomework: Study load factor vs bank angle
instructorNotes: Watch for student spatial disorientation
Encourage looking outside, not at instruments
safetyConsiderations: Monitor for stall at increased load factor

title: Straight-and-Level Flight
overview: Straight-and-level is the foundation of all flight. Students learn pitch, power, and trim relationships while developing the visual and instrument scan patterns essential for all flying.

keyPoints: Visual attitude more important than instruments

keyTeachingPoints: Pitch controls altitude (primarily), power controls airspeed (primarily)
Trim removes control pressures - critical for precision
Visual attitude reference is primary, instruments confirm
Scan: attitude, altitude, heading, airspeed, engine instruments
Small corrections early prevent large deviations
If altitude drifts: pitch first, then trim
Cruise power setting from POH (typically 65-75%)
commonErrors: Chasing altitude with excessive control inputs

diagrams.title: Pitch-Power-Trim Triangle
diagrams.asciiArt:
PITCH
     / \
    /   \
POWER - TRIM
All three must work together

notes: Seems simple but requires constant practice
instructorNotes: Be patient - this takes time to master
Encourage relaxed grip on controls

title: Level Turns
objectives: Maintain standard rate or specified bank angle
overview: Level turns teach coordination, altitude control during maneuvering, and the use of aileron-rudder coordination. Students learn shallow, medium, and steep turns while maintaining precise altitude.

instructorActions: Explain turn entry: bank, back pressure, trim
keyPoints: Altitude requires back pressure in turns

studentActions: Note back pressure in each bank angle
keyPoints: Lead rollout by half bank angle

keyTeachingPoints: Coordinated flight: ball centered, no slipping or skidding
Bank angle determines turn rate
Back pressure needed in turns to maintain altitude
Steeper bank = more back pressure
Lead rollout by approximately half the bank angle
Trim off control pressures in prolonged turns
Standard rate = 3° per second (360° in 2 minutes)
commonErrors: Rolling in without rudder - adverse yaw
Not adding back pressure - descending turn

diagrams.title: Coordinated vs Uncoordinated Flight
diagrams.asciiArt:
Coordinated:  ( O )  ← Ball centered
Skid:        (O  )   ← Too much rudder
Slip:        (  O)   ← Not enough rudder

instructorNotes: Watch for student cross-controlling
Emphasize smooth, coordinated inputs
safetyConsiderations: Monitor for uncoordinated flight at low altitude
Watch for stall in steep turns

title: Learning Process
objectives: Apply learning theories to flight instruction
Recognize the domains of learning (cognitive, affective, psychomotor)
Use the laws of learning in lesson planning
Assess learning plateaus and strategies to overcome them
overview: Understanding how learning occurs is fundamental to effective instruction. This lesson covers learning theories, domains of learning, characteristics of learning, and practical applications for flight instruction.

instructorActions: Ask: How did you learn to ride a bike?
keyPoints: Learning is change in behavior through experience

instructorActions: Show how flight training uses all three
Present REEPIR: Readiness, Exercise, Effect, Primacy, Intensity, Recency

keyTeachingPoints: Learning is change in behavior from experience
Three domains: Cognitive (know), Affective (feel), Psychomotor (do)
Laws of Learning (REEPIR): Readiness, Exercise, Effect, Primacy, Intensity, Recency
Stages of skill: Cognitive → Associative → Automatic
Learning plateaus are normal - vary practice to overcome
Positive reinforcement more effective than punishment
Spaced practice better than massed practice
commonErrors: Violating primacy - teaching incorrectly first time

completionStandards.standard: Explain at least three learning theories
Describe all three domains of learning
Apply laws of learning to instruction

instructorNotes: Encourage student participation
Share personal teaching failures and successes

title: Principles of Flight
objectives: Explain the four forces of flight
Describe lift generation and Bernoulli's principle
Understand stalls and critical angle of attack
Explain load factor and its effects
Teach aerodynamic principles clearly and accurately
overview: Principles of Flight is the foundation of aeronautical knowledge. CFI candidates must be able to explain complex aerodynamic concepts simply and accurately. This lesson covers the four forces, lift generation, drag types, stability, and performance.

keyPoints: Level flight: Lift = Weight, Thrust = Drag
Angle of attack is critical, not airspeed

instructorActions: Explain parasite drag (form, interference, skin friction)
keyPoints: Total drag minimized at L/D max

instructorActions: Discuss stall in turns, slow flight
studentActions: Grasp that stalls occur at any speed
keyPoints: Stall occurs at critical AOA, always
Increased load factor increases stall speed

instructorActions: Show load factor vs bank angle chart

keyPoints: Theory explains what students feel in flight

keyTeachingPoints: Four forces: Lift, Weight, Thrust, Drag - must balance for equilibrium
Lift generated by pressure differential and Newton's 3rd law
Angle of attack determines lift coefficient
Critical angle of attack (16-18°) causes stall, regardless of airspeed
Parasite drag increases with speed², induced drag decreases with speed²
Load factor increases in turns - affects stall speed and structural limits
Region of reverse command: below L/D max, more power needed to fly slower
commonErrors: Confusing angle of attack with pitch attitude
Stating stall occurs at specific airspeed
Not understanding lift is primarily Newton's 3rd law
Confusing ground effect with increased lift

completionStandards.standard: Explain relationship between angle of attack and lift
Describe how stalls occur and critical angle of attack
Explain load factor effects on stall speed

notes: Complex topic - allow time for questions
suggestedHomework: Draw and label airfoil with pressure distribution
Calculate stall speeds at various bank angles
instructorNotes: Make theory relatable to actual flight
Avoid getting too technical - practical application matters
safetyConsiderations: Ensure student understands stall recovery before flight training

title: Emergency Descent
overview: Emergency descents are needed for cabin fire, depressurization, or other urgent situations requiring rapid altitude loss. Students learn to descend at maximum safe rate while maintaining aircraft control.

instructorActions: Discuss technique: power idle, pitch down, spiral if needed
keyPoints: Don't exceed VNO or flap speeds

instructorActions: Power idle, pitch down for descent speed
Level off smoothly at target altitude

studentActions: Level off at assigned altitude ±100 ft

keyPoints: Hope you never need it, but be ready

keyTeachingPoints: Emergency descent for: cabin fire, depressurization, engine fire
Configuration: power idle, pitch down, flaps as appropriate (check POH)
Airspeed: Below VNO, respect flap speed limits
Spiral descent increases rate and allows lookout below
Clear area before and during descent
Monitor for traffic continuously
Level off smoothly to avoid excessive G-load
commonErrors: Fixating on airspeed - losing situational awareness
Forgetting to extend flaps within speed limits

diagrams.title: Emergency Descent Spiral
diagrams.description: Spiraling descent maintains visual contact with intended landing area
diagrams.asciiArt:
Start altitude
        ↓
       ◯◯◯  ← Spiral
      ◯   ◯     (lookout below)
     ◯     ◯
    Target altitude

completionStandards.standard: Establish appropriate descent configuration and airspeed
Level off at specified altitude ±100 feet

notes: Rarely needed but critical when required
instructorNotes: Student may feel uncomfortable with steep descent - reassure
Emphasize this is controlled emergency, not panic
safetyConsiderations: Be aware of traffic - descending into their altitude
